description: A sacred underwater forest grove on Fish-Man Island where sunken ships gather and where a Poneglyph containing Joy Boy's apology letter is kept. The forest is filled with sunlight filtering through the water, creating a beautiful and mysterious atmosphere.

keyEvents.title: Robin Discovers Joy Boy's Poneglyph
keyEvents.description: Nico Robin finds and reads the Poneglyph in the Sea Forest, discovering it contains an apology letter from Joy Boy to the ancient Poseidon.
keyEvents.significance: This is the first mention of Joy Boy in the series and reveals important information about the Void Century.

keyEvents.title: Robin Explores the Sea Forest
keyEvents.description: Robin continues her archaeological investigation of the Sea Forest.
keyEvents.significance: Robin's exploration leads to the discovery of Joy Boy's message.

statusHistory.reason: The Sea Forest remains an important historical site on Fish-Man Island

description: An underwater kingdom located 10,000 meters below sea level, beneath the Red Line. Home to fish-men and merfolk, the island is protected by a massive bubble and ruled by the Neptune royal family. It has a tragic history of discrimination and slavery.

keyEvents.title: New Fish-Man Pirates Force Fumi-e Ritual
keyEvents.description: The New Fish-Man Pirates force citizens to step on Queen Otohime's image as a loyalty test.
keyEvents.significance: Demonstrates the extremism of the New Fish-Man Pirates and the division on the island.

keyEvents.title: History of Fish-Men and Human Relations Explained
keyEvents.description: Jinbe explains the 200-year history of discrimination between fish-men and humans that has shaped the island.
keyEvents.significance: Provides crucial context for understanding Fish-Man Island's current situation.

statusHistory.reason: Fish-Man Island remains under Neptune's rule despite the New Fish-Man Pirates' takeover attempt

description: A fortress built by Arlong in the East Blue that served as his base of operations. Its design was identical to Sabaody Park, where fish-men were sold as slaves, symbolizing Arlong's reversal of the power dynamic.

keyEvents.title: Nami's Flashback to Arlong Park
keyEvents.description: Nami experiences flashbacks to her eight years of suffering under Arlong at Arlong Park.
keyEvents.significance: Reminds viewers of Nami's trauma and the emotional weight of her conversation with Jinbe.

keyEvents.title: Connection to Sabaody Park Revealed
keyEvents.description: Nami realizes that Arlong Park's design was identical to Sabaody Park where fish-men were enslaved.
keyEvents.significance: Reveals how Arlong's trauma influenced his cruelty, showing the cycle of hatred.

statusHistory.reason: Destroyed by Luffy during his battle with Arlong

description: An archipelago near the Red Line where the Human Auctioning House operates. Fish-men and other races were sold as slaves at Sabaody Park, a location that shares its design with Arlong Park.

keyEvents.title: Nami Recalls Sabaody Park
keyEvents.description: Nami recalls seeing the Human Auctioning House at Sabaody two years ago and realizes its connection to Arlong Park.
keyEvents.significance: Connects Arlong's oppression of Nami to the broader history of fish-men slavery.
